Package Funds.Tools.BookExport

Class BookExport

  • java.lang.Object
    • Funds.Tools.BookExport.BookExport
  • public class BookExport
extends java.lang.Object
    Object to export the data in one of the big four standards: xml, json, csv, sql

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      BookExport​(Book book, ExportType type)
      To export the data need to know what book holds the data and how to export it

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      void createTransactionCSV​(java.io.File file, Transaction[] transactions)
      Writes the csv file of data about a collection of transactions (such as all the transactions in a given account)
      java.lang.String getJSONString​(Account[] accounts)
      generates a string of JSON formatted account data
      java.lang.String getXMLString​(java.lang.String root, Account[] accounts)
      Generates a string of xml data representing the current state of an account
      void write()
      In an attempt to preserve structure this method sets up a directory structure for each of the main types and all their subcategories, and then writes each account to its own file, with the obvious exception of SQL where it is one big initialize_book-name_DB.sql text file which will preserve the structure in keyed tables

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • BookExport

        public BookExport​(Book book,
                  ExportType type)
        To export the data need to know what book holds the data and how to export it
        Parameters:
        book - the current working book
        type - the enumerated type of export

    • Method Detail

      • write

        public void write()
        In an attempt to preserve structure this method sets up a directory structure for each of the main types and all their subcategories, and then writes each account to its own file, with the obvious exception of SQL where it is one big initialize_book-name_DB.sql text file which will preserve the structure in keyed tables

      • getXMLString

        public java.lang.String getXMLString​(java.lang.String root,
                                     Account[] accounts)
        Generates a string of xml data representing the current state of an account
        Parameters:
        accounts - the account data object to be formatted
        Returns:
        String in pretty-print ready to be written to an xml file

      • getJSONString

        public java.lang.String getJSONString​(Account[] accounts)
        generates a string of JSON formatted account data
        Parameters:
        accounts - The account to convert from .fabk form to json format
        Returns:
        String ready to be written to a json file in pretty-print

      • createTransactionCSV

        public void createTransactionCSV​(java.io.File file,
                                 Transaction[] transactions)
        Writes the csv file of data about a collection of transactions (such as all the transactions in a given account)
        Parameters:
        file - the java file object to write to
        transactions - an array of Transaction objects to export for data storage elsewhere
